hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "Whoever frees a Muslim slave, Allah will save all the parts of his body from the 
(Hell) Fire as he has freed the body-parts of the slave." Sa`id bin Marjana said that he narrated that 
Hadith to `Ali bin Al-Husain and he freed his slave for whom `Abdullah bin Ja`far had offered him ten 
thousand Dirhams or one-thousand Dinars.
question: What is the significance of freeing a Muslim slave in Islam?

hadith-eng:
I asked the Prophet, "What is the best deed?" He replied, "To believe in Allah and to fight for His 
Cause." I then asked, "What is the best kind of manumission (of slaves)?" He replied, "The 
manumission of the most expensive slave and the most beloved by his master." I said, "If I cannot 
afford to do that?" He said, "Help the weak or do good for a person who cannot work for himself." I 
said, "If I cannot do that?" He said, "Refrain from harming others for this will be regarded as a 
charitable deed for your own good."
question: What is considered the best deed in Islam according to the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: The Prophet (ﷺ) ordered us to free slaves at the time of solar eclipses.
question: What actions are recommended during a solar eclipse according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: We were ordered to free slaves at the time of lunar eclipses.
question: What actions were recommended during lunar eclipses in early Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "Whoever manumits a slave owned by two masters, should manumit him 
completely (not partially) if he is rich after having its price evaluated."
question: What is the ruling on manumitting a slave owned by two masters in Islam?

hadith-eng:
Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, "Whoever frees his share of a common slave and he has sufficient money to free 
him completely, should let its price be estimated by a just man and give his partners the price of their 
shares and manumit the slave; otherwise (i.e. if he has not sufficient money) he manumits the slave 
partially."
question: What is the process for freeing a common slave when one partner has sufficient funds?

hadith-eng:
Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, "Whoever manumits his share of a slave, then it is essential for him to get that 
slave manumitted' completely as long as he has the money to do so. If he has not sufficient money to 
pay the price of the other shares (after the price of the slave is evaluated justly), the manumitted 
manumits the slave partially in proportion to his share.`Ubaidullah narrated as above in brief.
question: What is the significance of manumitting a slave in Islam?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "He who manumits his share of a slave and has money sufficient to free the 
remaining portion of that slave's price (justly estimated) then he should manumit him (by giving the 
rest of his price to the other co-owners)." Nafi` added, "Otherwise the slave is partially free." Aiyub is 
not sure whether the last statement was said by Nafi` or it was a part of the Hadith.
question: What is the ruling on freeing a slave when one co-owner decides to manumit his share?

hadith-eng:
That he used to give his verdict regarding the male or female slaves owned by more than one master, 
one of whom may manumit his share of the slave. Ibn `Umar used to say in such a case, "The 
manumitted should manumit the slave completely if he has sufficient money to pay the rest of the 
price of that slave (which is to be justly estimated) and the other shareholders are to take the price of 
their shares and the slave is freed (released from slavery)." Ibn `Umar narrated this verdict from the 
Prophet.
question: What is the ruling on manumitting a slave who is owned by multiple masters?

hadith-eng: That the Prophet (ﷺ) said, "Whoever frees his portion of a (common) slave."
question: What is the significance of freeing a portion of a common slave in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "Whoever frees his portion of a common slave should free the slave completely by 
paying the rest of his price from his money if he has enough money; otherwise the price of the slave is 
to be estimated and the slave is to be helped to work without hardship till he pays the rest of his 
price."
question: What is the significance of freeing a slave in Islam and how should it be approached if the slave is partially owned?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "Allah has accepted my invocation to forgive what whispers in the hearts of my 
followers, unless they put it to action or utter it." (See Hadith No. 657 Vol. 8)
question: What is the significance of Allah forgiving the whispers in the hearts of believers?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "The (reward of) deeds depend on intentions, and every person will get the reward 
according to what he intends. So, whoever migrated for Allah and His Apostle, then his migration will 
be for Allah and His Apostle, and whoever migrated for worldly benefits or for marrying a woman, 
then his migration will be for what he migrated for." (See Hadith No. 1, Vol. 1)
question: How does intention affect the reward of one's actions in Islam?

hadith-eng:
When Abu Huraira accompanied by his slave set out intending to embrace Islam they lost each other 
on the way. The slave then came while Abu Huraira was sitting with the Prophet. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 
"O Abu Huraira! Your slave has come back." Abu Huraira said, "Indeed, I would like you to witness 
that I have manumitted him." That happened at the time when Abu Huraira recited (the following 
poetic verse):-- 'What a long tedious tiresome night! Nevertheless, it has delivered us From the land of 
Kufr (disbelief).
question: What is the significance of manumitting a slave in Islam?

hadith-eng:
On my way to the Prophet (ﷺ) I was reciting:-- 'What a long tedious tiresome night! Nevertheless, it has 
saved us From the land of Kufr (disbelief).' I had a slave who ran away from me on the way. When I 
went to the Prophet (ﷺ) and gave the pledge of allegiance for embracing Islam, the slave showed up while 
I was still with the Prophet (ﷺ) who remarked, "O Abu Huraira! Here is your slave!" I said, "I manumit 
him for Allah's Sake," and so I freed him.
question: What is the significance of freeing a slave for the sake of Allah in Islam?

hadith-eng:
When Abu Huraira accompanied by his slave came intending to embrace Islam, they lost each other 
on the way. (When the slave showed up) Abu Huraira said (to the Prophet), "I make you witness that 
the slave is free for Allah's Cause."
question: What is the significance of freeing a slave in Islam for the sake of Allah?

hadith-eng:
`Utba bin Abi Waqqas authorized his brother Sa`d bin Abi Waqqas to take the son of the slave-girl of 
Zam`a into his custody, telling him that the boy was his own (illegal) son. When Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) went 
(to Mecca) at the time of the Conquest, Sa`d took the son of the slave-girl of Zam`a to Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) 
and also brought 'Abu bin Zam`a with him and said, "O Allah's Messenger (ﷺ)! This is the son of my brother 
`Utba who authorized me to take him into my custody." 'Abu bin Zam`a said, "O Allah's Messenger (ﷺ)! He 
is my brother, the son of Zam`a's slave-girl and he was born on his bed." Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) looked at the 
son of the slave-girl of Zam`a and noticed much resemblance (to `Utba). Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, "It is for 
you, O 'Abu bin Zam`a as he was born on the bed of your father." Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) then told Sauda bint 
Zam`a to observe veil in the presence of the boy as he noticed the boy's resemblance to `Utba and 
Sauda was the wife of the Prophet (ﷺ) .
question: What is the significance of lineage and paternity in Islamic law as demonstrated in this scenario?

hadith-eng:
A man amongst us declared that his slave would be freed after his death. The Prophet (ﷺ) called for that 
slave and sold him. The slave died the same year.
question: What is the Islamic ruling on freeing a slave after the owner's death?

hadith-eng: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) forbade the selling or donating the Wala' of a freed slave.
question: What is the significance of the concept of Wala' in Islamic law?

hadith-eng: I bought Barirah but her masters put the condition that her Wala' would be for them. I told the Prophet (ﷺ) about it. He said (to me), "Manumit (free) her as her Wala' will be for the one who pays the price." So, I manumitted (freed) her. The Prophet (ﷺ) called Barirah and gave her the option of either staying with her husband or leaving him. She said, "Even if he gave me so much money, I would not stay with him," and so she preferred her freedom to her husband.
question: What is the significance of the concept of Wala' in Islamic law and how does it relate to the rights of freed slaves?

hadith-eng:
Some men of the Ansar asked for the permission of Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) and said, "Allow us to give up the 
ransom from our nephew Al-`Abbas. The Prophet (ﷺ) said (to them), "Do not leave (even) a Dirham (of 
his ransom).
question: What is the significance of adhering to justice and fairness in financial matters according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng:
My father told me that Hakim bin Hizam manumitted one-hundred slaves in the Pre-Islamic period of 
ignorance and slaughtered one-hundred camels (and distributed them in charity). When he embraced 
Islam he again slaughtered one-hundred camels and manumitted one-hundred slaves. Hakim said, "I 
asked Allah's Messenger (ﷺ), 'O Allah's Messenger (ﷺ)! What do you think about some good deeds I used to 
practice in the Pre-Islamic period of ignorance regarding them as deeds of righteousness?' Allah's 
Apostle said, "You have embraced Islam along with all those good deeds you did."
question: How does embracing Islam affect the good deeds performed before conversion?

hadith-eng:
When the delegates of the tribe of Hawazin came to the Prophet (ﷺ) and they requested him to return their 
properties and captives. The Prophet (ﷺ) stood up and said to them, "I have other people with me in this 
matter (as you see) and the most beloved statement to me is the true one; you may choose either the 
properties or the prisoners as I have delayed their distribution." The Prophet (ﷺ) had waited for them for 
more than ten days since his arrival from Ta'if. So, when it became evident to them that the Prophet (ﷺ) 
was not going to return them except one of the two, they said, "We choose our prisoners." The 
Prophet got up amongst the people and glorified and praised Allah as He deserved and said, "Then 
after, these brethren of yours have come to us with repentance, and I see it logical to return them the 
captives. So, whoever amongst you likes to do that as a favor, then he can do it, and whoever of you 
likes to stick to his share till we recompense him from the very first war booty which Allah will give 
us, then he can do so (i.e. give up the present captives)." The people unanimously said, "We do that 
(return the captives) willingly." The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "We do not know which of you has agreed to it and 
which have not, so go back and let your leaders forward us your decision." So, all the people then 
went back and discussed the matter with their leaders who returned and informed the Prophet (ﷺ) that all 
the people had willingly given their consent to return the captives. This is what has reached us about 
the captives of Hawazin. Narrated Anas that `Abbas said to the Prophet, "I paid for my ransom and 
`Aqil's ransom."
question: What approach did the Prophet (ﷺ) take when dealing with the requests of the tribe of Hawazin regarding their properties and captives?

hadith-eng:
When the delegates of the tribe of Hawazin came to the Prophet (ﷺ) and they requested him to return their 
properties and captives. The Prophet (ﷺ) stood up and said to them, "I have other people with me in this

question: What approach did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) take when dealing with the requests of the tribe of Hawazin regarding their properties and captives?

hadith-eng:
I wrote a letter to Nafi` and Nafi` wrote in reply to my letter that the Prophet (ﷺ) had suddenly attacked 
Bani Mustaliq without warning while they were heedless and their cattle were being watered at the 
places of water. Their fighting men were killed and their women and children were taken as captives; 
the Prophet (ﷺ) got Juwairiya on that day. Nafi` said that Ibn `Umar had told him the above narration and 
that Ibn `Umar was in that army.
question: What were the circumstances surrounding the attack on Bani Mustaliq by the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng:
I saw Abu Sa`id and asked him about coitus interruptus. Abu Sa`id said, "We went with Allah's 
Apostle, in the Ghazwa of Bani Al-Mustaliq and we captured some of the 'Arabs as captives, and the 
long separation from our wives was pressing us hard and we wanted to practice coitus interruptus. We 
asked Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) (whether it was permissible). He said, "It is better for you not to do so. No soul, 
(that which Allah has) destined to exist, up to the Day of Resurrection, but will definitely come, into 
existence."
question: What guidance did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) provide regarding the practice of coitus interruptus during the expedition of Bani Al-Mustaliq?

hadith-eng:
I have loved the people of the tribe of Bani Tamim ever since I heard, three things, Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) 
said about them. I heard him saying, These people (of the tribe of Bani Tamim) would stand firm 
against Ad-Dajjal." When the Sadaqat (gifts of charity) from that tribe came, Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, 
"These are the Sadaqat (i.e. charitable gifts) of our folk." `Aisha had a slave-girl from that tribe, and 
the Prophet (ﷺ) said to `Aisha, "Manumit her as she is a descendant of Ishmael (the Prophet).
question: What significance does the tribe of Bani Tamim hold in Islamic tradition according to the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng:
Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, "He who has a slave-girl and educates and treats her nicely and then manumits 
and marries her, will get a double reward."
question: What are the benefits of educating and treating a slave-girl nicely in Islam?

hadith-eng:
I saw Abu Dhar Al-Ghifari wearing a cloak, and his slave, too, was wearing a cloak. We asked him 
about that (i.e. how both were wearing similar cloaks). He replied, "Once I abused a man and he 
complained of me to the Prophet (ﷺ) . The Prophet (ﷺ) asked me, 'Did you abuse him by slighting his 
mother?' He added, 'Your slaves are your brethren upon whom Allah has given you authority. So, if 
one has one's brethren under one's control, one should feed them with the like of what one eats and 
clothe them with the like of what one wears. You should not overburden them with what they cannot 
bear, and if you do so, help them (in their hard job).
question: What guidance does Islam provide regarding the treatment of slaves or those under one's authority?

hadith-eng:
Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, "If a slave is honest and faithful to his master and worships his Lord (Allah) in a 
perfect manner, he will get a double reward."
question: What are the rewards for a slave who is honest and faithful to their master in Islam?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "He who has a slave-girl and teaches her good manners and improves her education 
and then manumits and marries her, will get a double reward; and any slave who observes Allah's 
right and his master's right will get a double reward."
question: What are the benefits of educating and freeing a slave-girl before marrying her?

hadith-eng:
Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, "A pious slave gets a double reward." Abu Huraira added: By Him in Whose 
Hands my soul is but for Jihad (i.e. holy battles), Hajj, and my duty to serve my mother, I would have 
loved to die as a slave.
question: What are the rewards for a pious slave in Islam?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "Goodness and comfort are for him who worships his Lord in a perfect manner and 
serves his master sincerely."
question: What are the benefits of worshiping Allah in a perfect manner?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "If a slave serves his Saiyid (i.e. master) sincerely and worships his Lord (Allah) 
perfectly, he will get a double reward."
question: What are the conditions under which a servant can receive a double reward in Islam?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "The Mamluk (slave) who worships his Lord in a perfect manner, and is dutiful, 
sincere and obedient to his Saiyid (master), will get a double reward."
question: What are the characteristics of a slave that lead to receiving a double reward in Islam?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "You should not say, 'Feed your lord (Rabbaka), help your lord in performing 
ablution, or give water to your lord, but should say, 'my master (e.g. Feed your master instead of lord 
etc.) (Saiyidi), or my guardian (Maulai), and one should not say, my slave (Abdi), or my girl-slave 
(Amati), but should say, my lad (Fatai), my lass (Fatati), and 'my boy (Ghulami).
question: What is the significance of using respectful language when addressing others in Islam?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "If one manumits his share of a common slave (Abd), and he has money sufficient 
to free the remaining portion of the price of the slave (justly estimated), then he should free the slave 
completely by paying the rest of his price; otherwise the slave is freed partly. "
question: What is the ruling on freeing a slave when one co-owner decides to manumit his share?

hadith-eng:
Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, "Everyone of you is a guardian and is responsible for his charges. The ruler who 
has authority over people, is a guardian and is responsible for them, a man is a guardian of his family 
and is responsible for them; a woman is a guardian of her husband's house and children and is 
responsible for them; a slave ('Abu) is a guardian of his master's property and is responsible for it; so 
all of you are guardians and are responsible for your charges."
question: What are the responsibilities of individuals in different roles according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "If a slave-girl (Ama) commits illegal sexual intercourse, scourge her; if she does it 
again, scourge her again; if she repeats it, scourge her again." The narrator added that on the third or 
the fourth offense, the Prophet (ﷺ) said, "Sell her even for a hair rope."
question: What are the consequences for a slave-girl who repeatedly commits illegal sexual intercourse according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "When your servant brings your meals to you then if he does not let him sit and 
share the meals, then he should at least give him a mouthful or two mouthfuls of that meal or a meal 
or two meals, as he has prepared it."
question: What is the significance of sharing meals with those who serve us in Islam?

hadith-eng:
That he heard Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) saying, "Everyone of you is a guardian and is responsible for his 
charge; the ruler is a guardian and is responsible for his subjects; the man is a guardian in his family 
and responsible for his charges; a woman is a guardian of her husband's house and responsible for her 
charges; and the servant is a guardian of his master's property and is responsible for his charge." I 
definitely heard the above from the Prophet (ﷺ) and think that the Prophet (ﷺ) also said, "A man is a guardian 
of his father's property and responsible for his charges; so everyone of you is a guardian and 
responsible for his charges."
question: What are the responsibilities of a ruler towards their subjects in Islam?

hadith-eng: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "If somebody fights (or beats somebody) then he should avoid the face."
question: What guidance does Islam provide regarding physical altercations and the treatment of others?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "Whoever frees a Muslim slave, Allah will save all the parts of his body from the 
(Hell) Fire as he has freed the body-parts of the slave." Sa`id bin Marjana said that he narrated that 
Hadith to `Ali bin Al-Husain and he freed his slave for whom `Abdullah bin Ja`far had offered him ten 
thousand Dirhams or one-thousand Dinars.
question: How does freeing a slave relate to one's salvation from Hellfire?

hadith-eng:
I asked the Prophet, "What is the best deed?" He replied, "To believe in Allah and to fight for His 
Cause." I then asked, "What is the best kind of manumission (of slaves)?" He replied, "The 
manumission of the most expensive slave and the most beloved by his master." I said, "If I cannot 
afford to do that?" He said, "Help the weak or do good for a person who cannot work for himself." I 
said, "If I cannot do that?" He said, "Refrain from harming others for this will be regarded as a 
charitable deed for your own good."
question: What is the significance of manumission of slaves in Islam, and what criteria make it the best kind?

hadith-eng: The Prophet (ﷺ) ordered us to free slaves at the time of solar eclipses.
question: What is the significance of freeing slaves in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: We were ordered to free slaves at the time of lunar eclipses.
question: What is the significance of freeing slaves in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "Whoever manumits a slave owned by two masters, should manumit him 
completely (not partially) if he is rich after having its price evaluated."
question: How should the price of a slave be evaluated if one of the owners wishes to manumit him?

hadith-eng:
Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, "Whoever frees his share of a common slave and he has sufficient money to free 
him completely, should let its price be estimated by a just man and give his partners the price of their 
shares and manumit the slave; otherwise (i.e. if he has not sufficient money) he manumits the slave 
partially."
question: How should the price of a slave be determined when one partner wishes to manumit their share?

hadith-eng:
Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, "Whoever manumits his share of a slave, then it is essential for him to get that 
slave manumitted' completely as long as he has the money to do so. If he has not sufficient money to 
pay the price of the other shares (after the price of the slave is evaluated justly), the manumitted 
manumits the slave partially in proportion to his share.`Ubaidullah narrated as above in brief.
question: What should a person do if they own a share of a slave and wish to free them?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "He who manumits his share of a slave and has money sufficient to free the 
remaining portion of that slave's price (justly estimated) then he should manumit him (by giving the 
rest of his price to the other co-owners)." Nafi` added, "Otherwise the slave is partially free." Aiyub is 
not sure whether the last statement was said by Nafi` or it was a part of the Hadith.
question: How should the remaining price of a slave be handled if one co-owner has sufficient funds to free the entire slave?

hadith-eng:
That he used to give his verdict regarding the male or female slaves owned by more than one master, 
one of whom may manumit his share of the slave. Ibn `Umar used to say in such a case, "The 
manumitted should manumit the slave completely if he has sufficient money to pay the rest of the 
price of that slave (which is to be justly estimated) and the other shareholders are to take the price of 
their shares and the slave is freed (released from slavery)." Ibn `Umar narrated this verdict from the 
Prophet.
question: How should the price of a slave be estimated if one master wishes to free their share?

hadith-eng: That the Prophet (ﷺ) said, "Whoever frees his portion of a (common) slave."
question: How does the concept of shared ownership of a slave impact the decision to free them?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "Whoever frees his portion of a common slave should free the slave completely by 
paying the rest of his price from his money if he has enough money; otherwise the price of the slave is 
to be estimated and the slave is to be helped to work without hardship till he pays the rest of his 
price."
question: How should a person handle the financial responsibility when freeing a slave they partially own?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "Allah has accepted my invocation to forgive what whispers in the hearts of my 
followers, unless they put it to action or utter it." (See Hadith No. 657 Vol. 8)
question: Under what conditions are the whispers in the hearts of believers not held against them?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "The (reward of) deeds depend on intentions, and every person will get the reward 
according to what he intends. So, whoever migrated for Allah and His Apostle, then his migration will 
be for Allah and His Apostle, and whoever migrated for worldly benefits or for marrying a woman, 
then his migration will be for what he migrated for." (See Hadith No. 1, Vol. 1)
question: What are the implications of migrating for different purposes according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng:
When Abu Huraira accompanied by his slave set out intending to embrace Islam they lost each other 
on the way. The slave then came while Abu Huraira was sitting with the Prophet. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 
"O Abu Huraira! Your slave has come back." Abu Huraira said, "Indeed, I would like you to witness 
that I have manumitted him." That happened at the time when Abu Huraira recited (the following 
poetic verse):-- 'What a long tedious tiresome night! Nevertheless, it has delivered us From the land of 
Kufr (disbelief).
question: How did Abu Huraira express his gratitude upon reuniting with his slave?

hadith-eng:
On my way to the Prophet (ﷺ) I was reciting:-- 'What a long tedious tiresome night! Nevertheless, it has 
saved us From the land of Kufr (disbelief).' I had a slave who ran away from me on the way. When I 
went to the Prophet (ﷺ) and gave the pledge of allegiance for embracing Islam, the slave showed up while 
I was still with the Prophet (ﷺ) who remarked, "O Abu Huraira! Here is your slave!" I said, "I manumit 
him for Allah's Sake," and so I freed him.
question: How does embracing Islam influence one's actions towards others, as demonstrated in this narration?

hadith-eng:
When Abu Huraira accompanied by his slave came intending to embrace Islam, they lost each other 
on the way. (When the slave showed up) Abu Huraira said (to the Prophet), "I make you witness that 
the slave is free for Allah's Cause."
question: How does embracing Islam impact the actions and decisions of new converts?

hadith-eng:
`Utba bin Abi Waqqas authorized his brother Sa`d bin Abi Waqqas to take the son of the slave-girl of 
Zam`a into his custody, telling him that the boy was his own (illegal) son. When Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) went 
(to Mecca) at the time of the Conquest, Sa`d took the son of the slave-girl of Zam`a to Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) 
and also brought 'Abu bin Zam`a with him and said, "O Allah's Messenger (ﷺ)! This is the son of my brother 
`Utba who authorized me to take him into my custody." 'Abu bin Zam`a said, "O Allah's Messenger (ﷺ)! He 
is my brother, the son of Zam`a's slave-girl and he was born on his bed." Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) looked at the 
son of the slave-girl of Zam`a and noticed much resemblance (to `Utba). Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, "It is for 
you, O 'Abu bin Zam`a as he was born on the bed of your father." Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) then told Sauda bint 
Zam`a to observe veil in the presence of the boy as he noticed the boy's resemblance to `Utba and 
Sauda was the wife of the Prophet (ﷺ) .
question: How does Islamic tradition address the issue of resemblance in determining familial relationships?

hadith-eng:
A man amongst us declared that his slave would be freed after his death. The Prophet (ﷺ) called for that 
slave and sold him. The slave died the same year.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) handle the situation when a slave was declared to be freed after the owner's death?

hadith-eng: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) forbade the selling or donating the Wala' of a freed slave.
question: Why is the selling or donating of Wala' prohibited in Islam?

hadith-eng: I bought Barirah but her masters put the condition that her Wala' would be for them. I told the Prophet (ﷺ) about it. He said (to me), "Manumit (free) her as her Wala' will be for the one who pays the price." So, I manumitted (freed) her. The Prophet (ﷺ) called Barirah and gave her the option of either staying with her husband or leaving him. She said, "Even if he gave me so much money, I would not stay with him," and so she preferred her freedom to her husband.
question: How does Islam address the issue of a slave's choice in marital matters after gaining freedom?

hadith-eng:
Some men of the Ansar asked for the permission of Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) and said, "Allow us to give up the 
ransom from our nephew Al-`Abbas. The Prophet (ﷺ) said (to them), "Do not leave (even) a Dirham (of 
his ransom).
question: How does Islam view the concept of favoritism or partiality in legal and financial dealings?

hadith-eng:
My father told me that Hakim bin Hizam manumitted one-hundred slaves in the Pre-Islamic period of 
ignorance and slaughtered one-hundred camels (and distributed them in charity). When he embraced 
Islam he again slaughtered one-hundred camels and manumitted one-hundred slaves. Hakim said, "I 
asked Allah's Messenger (ﷺ), 'O Allah's Messenger (ﷺ)! What do you think about some good deeds I used to 
practice in the Pre-Islamic period of ignorance regarding them as deeds of righteousness?' Allah's 
Apostle said, "You have embraced Islam along with all those good deeds you did."
question: What is the significance of charity and freeing slaves in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng:
When the delegates of the tribe of Hawazin came to the Prophet (ﷺ) and they requested him to return their 
properties and captives. The Prophet (ﷺ) stood up and said to them, "I have other people with me in this 
matter (as you see) and the most beloved statement to me is the true one; you may choose either the 
properties or the prisoners as I have delayed their distribution." The Prophet (ﷺ) had waited for them for 
more than ten days since his arrival from Ta'if. So, when it became evident to them that the Prophet (ﷺ) 
was not going to return them except one of the two, they said, "We choose our prisoners." The 
Prophet got up amongst the people and glorified and praised Allah as He deserved and said, "Then 
after, these brethren of yours have come to us with repentance, and I see it logical to return them the 
captives. So, whoever amongst you likes to do that as a favor, then he can do it, and whoever of you 
likes to stick to his share till we recompense him from the very first war booty which Allah will give 
us, then he can do so (i.e. give up the present captives)." The people unanimously said, "We do that 
(return the captives) willingly." The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "We do not know which of you has agreed to it and 
which have not, so go back and let your leaders forward us your decision." So, all the people then 
went back and discussed the matter with their leaders who returned and informed the Prophet (ﷺ) that all 
the people had willingly given their consent to return the captives. This is what has reached us about 
the captives of Hawazin. Narrated Anas that `Abbas said to the Prophet, "I paid for my ransom and 
`Aqil's ransom."
question: How did the Prophet (ﷺ) involve his companions in the decision-making process concerning the captives of Hawazin?

hadith-eng:

properties and captives. The Prophet (ﷺ) stood up and said to them, "I have other people with me in this

question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) involve his companions in the decision-making process concerning the captives of Hawazin?

hadith-eng:
I wrote a letter to Nafi` and Nafi` wrote in reply to my letter that the Prophet (ﷺ) had suddenly attacked 
Bani Mustaliq without warning while they were heedless and their cattle were being watered at the 
places of water. Their fighting men were killed and their women and children were taken as captives; 
the Prophet (ﷺ) got Juwairiya on that day. Nafi` said that Ibn `Umar had told him the above narration and 
that Ibn `Umar was in that army.
question: What was the outcome for the women and children of Bani Mustaliq after the attack?

hadith-eng:
I saw Abu Sa`id and asked him about coitus interruptus. Abu Sa`id said, "We went with Allah's 
Apostle, in the Ghazwa of Bani Al-Mustaliq and we captured some of the 'Arabs as captives, and the 
long separation from our wives was pressing us hard and we wanted to practice coitus interruptus. We 
asked Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) (whether it was permissible). He said, "It is better for you not to do so. No soul, 
(that which Allah has) destined to exist, up to the Day of Resurrection, but will definitely come, into 
existence."
question: How does Islamic teaching address the concept of destiny and the existence of souls?

hadith-eng:
I have loved the people of the tribe of Bani Tamim ever since I heard, three things, Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) 
said about them. I heard him saying, These people (of the tribe of Bani Tamim) would stand firm 
against Ad-Dajjal." When the Sadaqat (gifts of charity) from that tribe came, Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, 
"These are the Sadaqat (i.e. charitable gifts) of our folk." `Aisha had a slave-girl from that tribe, and 
the Prophet (ﷺ) said to `Aisha, "Manumit her as she is a descendant of Ishmael (the Prophet).
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) express his appreciation for the charitable acts of the Bani Tamim tribe?

hadith-eng:
Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, "He who has a slave-girl and educates and treats her nicely and then manumits 
and marries her, will get a double reward."
question: How does marrying a manumitted slave-girl affect the reward one receives in Islam?

hadith-eng:
I saw Abu Dhar Al-Ghifari wearing a cloak, and his slave, too, was wearing a cloak. We asked him 
about that (i.e. how both were wearing similar cloaks). He replied, "Once I abused a man and he 
complained of me to the Prophet (ﷺ) . The Prophet (ﷺ) asked me, 'Did you abuse him by slighting his 
mother?' He added, 'Your slaves are your brethren upon whom Allah has given you authority. So, if 
one has one's brethren under one's control, one should feed them with the like of what one eats and 
clothe them with the like of what one wears. You should not overburden them with what they cannot 
bear, and if you do so, help them (in their hard job).
question: How does Islam emphasize equality and brotherhood among people, regardless of their social status?

hadith-eng:
Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, "If a slave is honest and faithful to his master and worships his Lord (Allah) in a 
perfect manner, he will get a double reward."
question: How does perfect worship of Allah contribute to a person's reward according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "He who has a slave-girl and teaches her good manners and improves her education 
and then manumits and marries her, will get a double reward; and any slave who observes Allah's 
right and his master's right will get a double reward."
question: How does observing the rights of Allah and one's master lead to a double reward for a slave?

hadith-eng:
Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, "A pious slave gets a double reward." Abu Huraira added: By Him in Whose 
Hands my soul is but for Jihad (i.e. holy battles), Hajj, and my duty to serve my mother, I would have 
loved to die as a slave.
question: How does the concept of Jihad, Hajj, and serving one's mother relate to personal aspirations in Islam?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "Goodness and comfort are for him who worships his Lord in a perfect manner and 
serves his master sincerely."
question: How does sincere service to one's master relate to receiving goodness and comfort?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "If a slave serves his Saiyid (i.e. master) sincerely and worships his Lord (Allah) 
perfectly, he will get a double reward."
question: How does sincere service to one's master relate to worship in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "The Mamluk (slave) who worships his Lord in a perfect manner, and is dutiful, 
sincere and obedient to his Saiyid (master), will get a double reward."
question: How does sincerity and obedience impact the spiritual rewards for a person in servitude?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "You should not say, 'Feed your lord (Rabbaka), help your lord in performing 
ablution, or give water to your lord, but should say, 'my master (e.g. Feed your master instead of lord 
etc.) (Saiyidi), or my guardian (Maulai), and one should not say, my slave (Abdi), or my girl-slave 
(Amati), but should say, my lad (Fatai), my lass (Fatati), and 'my boy (Ghulami).
question: How does the choice of words reflect one's attitude towards others in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "If one manumits his share of a common slave (Abd), and he has money sufficient 
to free the remaining portion of the price of the slave (justly estimated), then he should free the slave 
completely by paying the rest of his price; otherwise the slave is freed partly. "
question: How should the remaining price of a slave be handled if one co-owner has sufficient funds to free the entire slave?

hadith-eng:
Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, "Everyone of you is a guardian and is responsible for his charges. The ruler who 
has authority over people, is a guardian and is responsible for them, a man is a guardian of his family 
and is responsible for them; a woman is a guardian of her husband's house and children and is 
responsible for them; a slave ('Abu) is a guardian of his master's property and is responsible for it; so 
all of you are guardians and are responsible for your charges."
question: How does Islam emphasize the concept of guardianship and accountability?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "If a slave-girl (Ama) commits illegal sexual intercourse, scourge her; if she does it 
again, scourge her again; if she repeats it, scourge her again." The narrator added that on the third or 
the fourth offense, the Prophet (ﷺ) said, "Sell her even for a hair rope."
question: How does Islamic law address repeated offenses of illegal sexual intercourse by a slave-girl?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "When your servant brings your meals to you then if he does not let him sit and 
share the meals, then he should at least give him a mouthful or two mouthfuls of that meal or a meal 
or two meals, as he has prepared it."
question: How does Islam emphasize the treatment of servants and workers in daily life?

hadith-eng:
That he heard Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) saying, "Everyone of you is a guardian and is responsible for his 
charge; the ruler is a guardian and is responsible for his subjects; the man is a guardian in his family 
and responsible for his charges; a woman is a guardian of her husband's house and responsible for her 
charges; and the servant is a guardian of his master's property and is responsible for his charge." I 
definitely heard the above from the Prophet (ﷺ) and think that the Prophet (ﷺ) also said, "A man is a guardian 
of his father's property and responsible for his charges; so everyone of you is a guardian and 
responsible for his charges."
question: How does Islam define the role of a man within his family?

hadith-eng: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "If somebody fights (or beats somebody) then he should avoid the face."
question: Why is it important to avoid striking the face during a conflict according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "Whoever frees a Muslim slave, Allah will save all the parts of his body from the 
(Hell) Fire as he has freed the body-parts of the slave." Sa`id bin Marjana said that he narrated that 
Hadith to `Ali bin Al-Husain and he freed his slave for whom `Abdullah bin Ja`far had offered him ten 
thousand Dirhams or one-thousand Dinars.
question: What actions did Ali bin Al-Husain take upon hearing the hadith about freeing a slave?

hadith-eng:
I asked the Prophet, "What is the best deed?" He replied, "To believe in Allah and to fight for His 
Cause." I then asked, "What is the best kind of manumission (of slaves)?" He replied, "The 
manumission of the most expensive slave and the most beloved by his master." I said, "If I cannot 
afford to do that?" He said, "Help the weak or do good for a person who cannot work for himself." I 
said, "If I cannot do that?" He said, "Refrain from harming others for this will be regarded as a 
charitable deed for your own good."
question: How can one perform charitable deeds if they are unable to afford manumission or help the weak directly?

hadith-eng: The Prophet (ﷺ) ordered us to free slaves at the time of solar eclipses.
question: How does Islam view the act of freeing slaves in relation to celestial events?

hadith-eng: We were ordered to free slaves at the time of lunar eclipses.
question: How were natural phenomena like lunar eclipses linked to social actions in Islamic history?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "Whoever manumits a slave owned by two masters, should manumit him 
completely (not partially) if he is rich after having its price evaluated."
question: What financial condition must be met by a person who wishes to fully manumit a jointly owned slave?

hadith-eng:
Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, "Whoever frees his share of a common slave and he has sufficient money to free 
him completely, should let its price be estimated by a just man and give his partners the price of their 
shares and manumit the slave; otherwise (i.e. if he has not sufficient money) he manumits the slave 
partially."
question: What should be done if a partner does not have enough money to fully manumit a common slave?

hadith-eng:
Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, "Whoever manumits his share of a slave, then it is essential for him to get that 
slave manumitted' completely as long as he has the money to do so. If he has not sufficient money to 
pay the price of the other shares (after the price of the slave is evaluated justly), the manumitted 
manumits the slave partially in proportion to his share.`Ubaidullah narrated as above in brief.
question: How is the financial responsibility determined when manumitting a partially owned slave?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "He who manumits his share of a slave and has money sufficient to free the 
remaining portion of that slave's price (justly estimated) then he should manumit him (by giving the 
rest of his price to the other co-owners)." Nafi` added, "Otherwise the slave is partially free." Aiyub is 
not sure whether the last statement was said by Nafi` or it was a part of the Hadith.
question: What happens to a slave if only a portion of him is manumitted by one of the co-owners?

hadith-eng:
That he used to give his verdict regarding the male or female slaves owned by more than one master, 
one of whom may manumit his share of the slave. Ibn `Umar used to say in such a case, "The 
manumitted should manumit the slave completely if he has sufficient money to pay the rest of the 
price of that slave (which is to be justly estimated) and the other shareholders are to take the price of 
their shares and the slave is freed (released from slavery)." Ibn `Umar narrated this verdict from the 
Prophet.
question: What should happen if a master has sufficient funds to pay for the remaining shares of a slave they wish to manumit?

hadith-eng: That the Prophet (ﷺ) said, "Whoever frees his portion of a (common) slave."
question: What are the implications of freeing a slave in terms of social and ethical responsibilities in Islam?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "Whoever frees his portion of a common slave should free the slave completely by 
paying the rest of his price from his money if he has enough money; otherwise the price of the slave is 
to be estimated and the slave is to be helped to work without hardship till he pays the rest of his 
price."
question: What measures should be taken to ensure a slave is not overburdened when working to pay off their price?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "Allah has accepted my invocation to forgive what whispers in the hearts of my 
followers, unless they put it to action or utter it." (See Hadith No. 657 Vol. 8)
question: How does intention differ from action in the context of accountability in Islam?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "The (reward of) deeds depend on intentions, and every person will get the reward 
according to what he intends. So, whoever migrated for Allah and His Apostle, then his migration will 
be for Allah and His Apostle, and whoever migrated for worldly benefits or for marrying a woman, 
then his migration will be for what he migrated for." (See Hadith No. 1, Vol. 1)
question: Why is it important to have sincere intentions when performing religious duties?

hadith-eng:
When Abu Huraira accompanied by his slave set out intending to embrace Islam they lost each other 
on the way. The slave then came while Abu Huraira was sitting with the Prophet. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 
"O Abu Huraira! Your slave has come back." Abu Huraira said, "Indeed, I would like you to witness 
that I have manumitted him." That happened at the time when Abu Huraira recited (the following 
poetic verse):-- 'What a long tedious tiresome night! Nevertheless, it has delivered us From the land of 
Kufr (disbelief).
question: What does the poetic verse recited by Abu Huraira signify about his journey from disbelief to faith?

hadith-eng:
On my way to the Prophet (ﷺ) I was reciting:-- 'What a long tedious tiresome night! Nevertheless, it has 
saved us From the land of Kufr (disbelief).' I had a slave who ran away from me on the way. When I 
went to the Prophet (ﷺ) and gave the pledge of allegiance for embracing Islam, the slave showed up while 
I was still with the Prophet (ﷺ) who remarked, "O Abu Huraira! Here is your slave!" I said, "I manumit 
him for Allah's Sake," and so I freed him.
question: What can be learned about the relationship between a master and a slave in the context of Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng:
When Abu Huraira accompanied by his slave came intending to embrace Islam, they lost each other 
on the way. (When the slave showed up) Abu Huraira said (to the Prophet), "I make you witness that 
the slave is free for Allah's Cause."
question: What role does witnessing play in the act of freeing a slave in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng:
`Utba bin Abi Waqqas authorized his brother Sa`d bin Abi Waqqas to take the son of the slave-girl of 
Zam`a into his custody, telling him that the boy was his own (illegal) son. When Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) went 
(to Mecca) at the time of the Conquest, Sa`d took the son of the slave-girl of Zam`a to Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) 
and also brought 'Abu bin Zam`a with him and said, "O Allah's Messenger (ﷺ)! This is the son of my brother 
`Utba who authorized me to take him into my custody." 'Abu bin Zam`a said, "O Allah's Messenger (ﷺ)! He 
is my brother, the son of Zam`a's slave-girl and he was born on his bed." Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) looked at the 
son of the slave-girl of Zam`a and noticed much resemblance (to `Utba). Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, "It is for 
you, O 'Abu bin Zam`a as he was born on the bed of your father." Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) then told Sauda bint 
Zam`a to observe veil in the presence of the boy as he noticed the boy's resemblance to `Utba and 
Sauda was the wife of the Prophet (ﷺ) .
question: What are the implications of observing the veil in the presence of certain individuals according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng:
A man amongst us declared that his slave would be freed after his death. The Prophet (ﷺ) called for that 
slave and sold him. The slave died the same year.
question: What can be learned about the Prophet's (ﷺ) decision-making in matters of inheritance and ownership?

hadith-eng: Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) forbade the selling or donating the Wala' of a freed slave.
question: How does the relationship between a freed slave and their former master change after emancipation in terms of Wala'?

hadith-eng: I bought Barirah but her masters put the condition that her Wala' would be for them. I told the Prophet (ﷺ) about it. He said (to me), "Manumit (free) her as her Wala' will be for the one who pays the price." So, I manumitted (freed) her. The Prophet (ﷺ) called Barirah and gave her the option of either staying with her husband or leaving him. She said, "Even if he gave me so much money, I would not stay with him," and so she preferred her freedom to her husband.
question: What role does the payment of a price play in the manumission of a slave according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng:
Some men of the Ansar asked for the permission of Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) and said, "Allow us to give up the 
ransom from our nephew Al-`Abbas. The Prophet (ﷺ) said (to them), "Do not leave (even) a Dirham (of 
his ransom).
question: What lessons can be learned about the importance of following the Prophet's guidance in matters of wealth and ransom?

hadith-eng:
My father told me that Hakim bin Hizam manumitted one-hundred slaves in the Pre-Islamic period of 
ignorance and slaughtered one-hundred camels (and distributed them in charity). When he embraced 
Islam he again slaughtered one-hundred camels and manumitted one-hundred slaves. Hakim said, "I 
asked Allah's Messenger (ﷺ), 'O Allah's Messenger (ﷺ)! What do you think about some good deeds I used to 
practice in the Pre-Islamic period of ignorance regarding them as deeds of righteousness?' Allah's 
Apostle said, "You have embraced Islam along with all those good deeds you did."
question: How are good deeds from the pre-Islamic period of ignorance viewed in Islam after conversion?

When the delegates of the tribe of Hawazin came to the Prophet (ﷺ) and they requested him to return their 
properties and captives. The Prophet (ﷺ) stood up and said to them, "I have other people with me in this 
matter (as you see) and the most beloved statement to me is the true one; you may choose either the

question: What does this incident teach about the importance of collective decision-making and consent in Islamic governance?

question: What does this incident teach about the importance of collective decision-making and mutual consent in resolving community issues?

that Ibn `Umar was in that army.
question: Who was Juwairiya and what was her significance in the context of the Bani Mustaliq incident?

hadith-eng:
I saw Abu Sa`id and asked him about coitus interruptus. Abu Sa`id said, "We went with Allah's 
Apostle, in the Ghazwa of Bani Al-Mustaliq and we captured some of the 'Arabs as captives, and the

(that which Allah has) destined to exist, up to the Day of Resurrection, but will definitely come, into 
existence."
question: What considerations should be taken into account when dealing with captives in the context of Islamic warfare?

I have loved the people of the tribe of Bani Tamim ever since I heard, three things, Allah's Messenger (ﷺ)

question: What is the importance of freeing slaves in Islam, as demonstrated by the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) in his interaction with Aisha's slave-girl?

hadith-eng:
Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, "He who has a slave-girl and educates and treats her nicely and then manumits 
and marries her, will get a double reward."
question: What is the significance of manumission in the context of Islamic teachings on slavery?

mother?' He added, 'Your slaves are your brethren upon whom Allah has given you authority. So, if 
one has one's brethren under one's control, one should feed them with the like of what one eats and 
clothe them with the like of what one wears. You should not overburden them with what they cannot 
bear, and if you do so, help them (in their hard job).
question: What responsibilities do those in authority have towards those who work for them according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng:
Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, "If a slave is honest and faithful to his master and worships his Lord (Allah) in a 
perfect manner, he will get a double reward."
question: What is the significance of receiving a double reward for certain actions in Islam?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "He who has a slave-girl and teaches her good manners and improves her education 
and then manumits and marries her, will get a double reward; and any slave who observes Allah's 
right and his master's right will get a double reward."
question: What actions can lead to receiving a double reward according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng:
Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, "A pious slave gets a double reward." Abu Huraira added: By Him in Whose 
Hands my soul is but for Jihad (i.e. holy battles), Hajj, and my duty to serve my mother, I would have 
loved to die as a slave.
question: What significance does serving one's mother hold in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "Goodness and comfort are for him who worships his Lord in a perfect manner and 
serves his master sincerely."
question: What is the significance of sincerity in worship and service according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "If a slave serves his Saiyid (i.e. master) sincerely and worships his Lord (Allah) 
perfectly, he will get a double reward."
question: What is the significance of perfect worship in earning rewards according to Islamic beliefs?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "The Mamluk (slave) who worships his Lord in a perfect manner, and is dutiful, 
sincere and obedient to his Saiyid (master), will get a double reward."
question: What is the significance of worshiping Allah in a perfect manner for those in servitude?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "You should not say, 'Feed your lord (Rabbaka), help your lord in performing 
ablution, or give water to your lord, but should say, 'my master (e.g. Feed your master instead of lord 
etc.) (Saiyidi), or my guardian (Maulai), and one should not say, my slave (Abdi), or my girl-slave 
(Amati), but should say, my lad (Fatai), my lass (Fatati), and 'my boy (Ghulami).
question: Why is it important to avoid terms that imply ownership or servitude when referring to others?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "If one manumits his share of a common slave (Abd), and he has money sufficient 
to free the remaining portion of the price of the slave (justly estimated), then he should free the slave 
completely by paying the rest of his price; otherwise the slave is freed partly. "
question: What happens to a slave if only a portion of him is freed by one of the owners?

hadith-eng:
Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, "Everyone of you is a guardian and is responsible for his charges. The ruler who 
has authority over people, is a guardian and is responsible for them, a man is a guardian of his family 
and is responsible for them; a woman is a guardian of her husband's house and children and is 
responsible for them; a slave ('Abu) is a guardian of his master's property and is responsible for it; so 
all of you are guardians and are responsible for your charges."
question: What is the significance of being a guardian in various social and familial contexts?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "If a slave-girl (Ama) commits illegal sexual intercourse, scourge her; if she does it 
again, scourge her again; if she repeats it, scourge her again." The narrator added that on the third or 
the fourth offense, the Prophet (ﷺ) said, "Sell her even for a hair rope."
question: What measures are prescribed in Islam for dealing with a slave-girl who continues to commit the same sin multiple times?

hadith-eng:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "When your servant brings your meals to you then if he does not let him sit and 
share the meals, then he should at least give him a mouthful or two mouthfuls of that meal or a meal 
or two meals, as he has prepared it."
question: What are the ethical considerations in Islam regarding the preparation and sharing of food?

hadith-eng:
That he heard Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) saying, "Everyone of you is a guardian and is responsible for his 
charge; the ruler is a guardian and is responsible for his subjects; the man is a guardian in his family 
and responsible for his charges; a woman is a guardian of her husband's house and responsible for her 
charges; and the servant is a guardian of his master's property and is responsible for his charge." I 
definitely heard the above from the Prophet (ﷺ) and think that the Prophet (ﷺ) also said, "A man is a guardian 
of his father's property and responsible for his charges; so everyone of you is a guardian and 
responsible for his charges."
question: What responsibilities does a woman have in her husband's household according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "If somebody fights (or beats somebody) then he should avoid the face."
question: How does Islamic teaching emphasize the dignity and respect of individuals even in situations of conflict?
